data.source: Quantitative online survey administered through an ISO-certified online access panel
data.sample_size: 1,242 respondents after data cleansing (1,300 completed the questionnaire)
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual adult (18–74 years old) residents of Germany
data.access_details: Panel provider handled programming and recruitment; dataset access not stated
data.notes: All questions were mandatory; sample is representative for gender, age and federal state distribution; respondents who finished in under seven minutes were removed

method.description: A structured online questionnaire covering risk perception, coping strategies and emergency food preparedness was distributed to a nationally representative German adult sample. Descriptive statistics and significance tests (e.g., p-values for group comparisons and correlations) were reported.
steps: Design questionnaire with sections on risk perception, coping (problem-focused and emotion-focused) and emergency food preparedness, plus socio-demographics
Program survey on panel provider platform; make all items mandatory
Recruit German adults (18+) via ISO-certified online panel between 19–23 March 2020
Exclude respondents who completed in less than seven minutes
Compute descriptive statistics (means, percentages) for all items
Conduct group comparisons (gender, age, federal state) and correlation analyses; report p-values
method.models: Descriptive statistics; bivariate tests for differences (e.g., t-tests, correlations)
method.outcome_variable: Perceived risk of COVID-19 infection, fear/worry, coping strategy endorsement, food preparedness behaviour
method.independent_variables: Age, gender, federal state, location type (urban/rural)

results.summary: Older respondents perceive a lower personal risk of COVID-19 infection than younger respondents. Women report greater worry and fear than men. Most people feel safe at home but few feel safe in public spaces or transport. Coping is predominantly problem-focused: respondents report following expert advice and avoiding risky situations. Around 42% report buying more food than usual, mainly to reduce shopping frequency and prepare for possible quarantine.

numerical_results.unit: 5-point Likert scale (1 = very likely, 5 = not very likely)

numerical_results.outcome_name: Gender difference in belief that infection is likely at some point (percentage)

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19: Risk perception and Coping strategies. Results from a survey in Germany.
